Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Real-time arrhythmia detection and classification using a waterproof armband
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to help identify people that have paroxysmal or asymptomatic cardiac arrhythmias before they become dangerous. Atrial Fibrillation (AF) is the most common arrhythmia, and the prevalence of AF increases with age. AF has a profound impact on longevity and quality of life. Patients typically develop paroxysmal, short-lived episodes of the arrhythmia and are frequently asymptomatic. This often leads to delays in diagnosis of AF until later stages when the arrhythmia is more persistent. Even short episodes of paroxysmal AF are associated with increased risk for stroke, heart failure, hospitalization, and death. The population with undiagnosed AF is substantial and studies have shown that continuous ECG monitoring for more than 3 years is required to achieve close to 100% AF detection. Current 30-day monitors detect 5% of paroxysmal and asymptomatic cases, since events must occur while the monitor is being worn. An armband-based approach offers a way to overcome the current restrictions in chest based monitors and bridges the gap between short-duration 30-day monitors and long-term implanted monitors.


The proposed project uses an armband-based device to capture electrocardiogram (ECG) and electromyogram (EMG) signals on the upper arm using a waterproof and wireless device. The sensors are made from a composite material that can operate both wet and dry and does not require adhesives or hydrogels to capture all aspects of the waveforms. The challenge with the upper arm is that the ECG signals have less magnitude then over-the-heart and it is necessary to remove motion / noise artifacts as well as EMG signals to create a clean ECG signal. The research is focused on embedding algorithms into the device and testing and refining them for removing motion and noise artifacts that are captured by an accelerometer and to remove EMG signals. After a clean signal is established, proven algorithms for classification of the arrhythmias can be run embedded in the device.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the NSF Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase 1 award was to enable continuous electrocardiogram (ECG) based arrhythmia detection and classification in a novel off-the-chest armband based device.

The Phase 1 project has the potential for a much broader impact on society. Currently only 33% of arrhythmias are detected and despite the release of novel new approaches like the Apple Watch to do 30-sec snapshot ECGs the watch is still limited to detect symptomatic and short-term atrial fibrillation. It is still necessary to do long term continuous monitoring to provide an accurate diagnosis that captures paroxysmal and asymptomatic arrhythmias which are one of the leading causes of stroke in the United States. Our research and development work has led to a novel, non-invasive approach to do continuous monitoring on the upper arm that does not require surgery and has the potential to go beyond 30-days of monitoring which patch based ECG monitoring is limited too.

Helping identify patients with arrythmias can help save lives and reduce the cost to the healthcare system by potentially preventing hospitalization and death associated with untreated and dangerous arrythmias.

This SBIR Phase I project had strong intellectual merit by helping prove that arrhythmia detection and classification is possible on the upper arm by overcoming the major challenges with this location due to the low magnitude ECG signals.

The primary outcome of our development was that we are able to capture clean and clear ECG signals on the upper arm. The approach required innovating new ways to do continuous and real-time detection of arrhythmias by 1) developing new algorithms to reduce motion noise artifacts to reveal the underlying signal 2) developing new hardware and algorithms that captured the electromyogram (EMG) from the bi-cep and tri-cep and canceled out these large magnitude signals to extract the ECG and 3) to reconstruct a clean ECG (Figure 1) that could be processed using a low power, high performance processor for real-time detection. The final signal as seen in Figure 2 shows the full ECG waveform morphology including standard PQRS features needed for a diagnosis by a doctor, the p-wave is clear and pronounced and the r and r intervals can be calculated in real-time. The signals collected are clear enough to calculate various cardiac arrhythmias including atrial fibrillation. The waveform should meet the requirements needed to start commercialization of the device as part of a Phase II project.
